subject: Gardening
title: What's Inside a Seed
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: What's Inside a Seed.

hook.text: A seed is a tiny survival capsule. Inside it sits everything a plant needs to start lifeâ€”just add water.

buildup.text: Every seed has three core parts: an embryo (the baby plant), endosperm (food supply), and seed coat (armor).

discovery.text: The endosperm is packed with starch, protein, and oilsâ€”fuel for growth until the seedling photosynthesizes.

twist.text: The endosperm is also what humans eat. Rice, wheat, and corn are all seedsâ€”we eat the baby plant's packed lunch.

climax.text: Seeds are simultaneously survival pods for plants and the foundation of human civilization's food supply.

punchline.text: When you eat rice, you're eating a baby plant's lunch.

quiz.question: What is the endosperm's role inside a seed?
options: It protects the seed from water damage
It provides food to fuel growth until the seedling can photosynthesize
It attracts pollinators to help the next generation
